title: Practical 4
text:
Question 1
# load nycflights13  flight data
data(flights, package = "nycflights13") 
flights <- as_tibble(flights)
flights

# A tibble: 336,776 × 19

title: Practical 4
text:
Question 1

# load nycflights13  flight data
data(flights, package = "nycflights13") 
flights <- as_tibble(flights)
flights

# A tibble: 336,776 × 19
    year month   day dep_time sched_dep_time dep_delay arr_time sched_arr_time
   <int> <int> <int>    <int>          <int>     <dbl>    <int>          <int>
 1  2013     1     1      517            515         2      830            819
 2  2013     1     1      533            529         4      850            830
 3  2013     1     1      542            540         2      923            850
 4  2013     1     1      544            545        -1     1004           1022
 5  2013     1     1      554            600        -6      812            837
 6  2013     1     1      554            558        -4      740            728
 7  2013     1     1      555            600        -5      913            854
 8  2013     1     1      557            600        -3      709            723
 9  2013     1     1      557            600        -3      838            846
10  2013     1     1      558            600        -2      753            745
# ℹ 336,766 more rows
# ℹ 11 more variables: arr_delay <dbl>, carrier <chr>, flight <int>,
#   tailnum <chr>, origin <chr>, dest <chr>, air_time <dbl>, distance <dbl>,
#   hour <dbl>, minute <dbl>, time_hour <dttm>

title: Practical 4
text:
Question 2

# Filter flights by month = 1 (January)
 flights_jan <- flights |> 
   filter(month == 1) |> 
   select(carrier,distance)
flights_jan

# A tibble: 27,004 × 2
   carrier distance
   <chr>      <dbl>
 1 UA          1400
 2 UA          1416
 3 AA          1089
 4 B6          1576
 5 DL           762
 6 UA           719
 7 B6          1065
 8 EV           229
 9 B6           944
10 AA           733
# ℹ 26,994 more rows



# Group the January flights by carrier
flights_jan_by_carrier <- flights_jan |> 
  group_by(carrier) |> 
  summarise(Mean = mean(distance), SD = sd(distance))
flights_jan_by_carrier

# A tibble: 16 × 3
   carrier  Mean    SD
   <chr>   <dbl> <dbl>
 1 9E       476. 334. 
 2 AA      1350. 626. 
 3 AS      2402    0  
 4 B6      1062. 681. 
 5 DL      1220. 644. 
 6 EV       522. 294. 
 7 F9      1620    0  
 8 FL       691. 142. 
 9 HA      4983    0  
10 MQ       566. 223. 
11 OO       733   NA  
12 UA      1462. 778. 
13 US       536. 553. 
14 VX      2495.  98.2
15 WN       942. 496. 
16 YV       229    0

title: Practical 4
text:
Question 3

# Filtering the January Flights to see all flights from the two carriers of interest
flights_jan |> 
  filter(carrier == "OO")

# A tibble: 1 × 2
  carrier distance
  <chr>      <dbl>
1 OO           733

flights_jan |> 
  filter(carrier == "F9")

# A tibble: 59 × 2
   carrier distance
   <chr>      <dbl>
 1 F9          1620
 2 F9          1620
 3 F9          1620
 4 F9          1620
 5 F9          1620
 6 F9          1620
 7 F9          1620
 8 F9          1620
 9 F9          1620
10 F9          1620
# ℹ 49 more rows


We can see that the carrier 00 has only one distance recorded in January, and that F9 has many, but all of them are equal to 1620.

# Make objects containing all the rows of flight distances from each carrier
distance.00 <- flights_jan |> 
  filter(carrier == "OO") |> 
    select(distance)
distance.F9 <- flights_jan |> 
  filter(carrier == "F9") |> 
    select(distance)
distance.00

# A tibble: 1 × 1
  distance
     <dbl>
1      733

distance.F9

# A tibble: 59 × 1
   distance
      <dbl>
 1     1620
 2     1620
 3     1620
 4     1620
 5     1620
 6     1620
 7     1620
 8     1620
 9     1620
10     1620
# ℹ 49 more rows



# Find the standard deviation of each of the carriers January flights.
sd.00 <- distance.00 |> 
  summarise(SD = sd(distance))
sd.F9 <-  distance.F9 |> 
  summarise(SD = sd(distance))
sd.00

# A tibble: 1 × 1
     SD
  <dbl>
1    NA

sd.F9

# A tibble: 1 × 1
     SD
  <dbl>
1     0


Carrier “00” only has one distance (or row), and so cannot have a standard deviation, hence the standard deviation is “na”.
Carrier “F9” has many distances but they are all equal, hence standard deviation is equal to 0.

title: Practical 4
text:
Question 4

# Flitering Flights for relevant columns
flights_dep_delay <- flights |> 
  select(month,dep_delay,carrier)
flights_dep_delay

# A tibble: 336,776 × 3
   month dep_delay carrier
   <int>     <dbl> <chr>  
 1     1         2 UA     
 2     1         4 UA     
 3     1         2 AA     
 4     1        -1 B6     
 5     1        -6 DL     
 6     1        -4 UA     
 7     1        -5 B6     
 8     1        -3 EV     
 9     1        -3 B6     
10     1        -2 AA     
# ℹ 336,766 more rows



# Averages per carrier per month
flights_dep_delay_averages <- flights_dep_delay |> 
  group_by(month,carrier) |> 
  summarise(avg_dep_delay = mean(dep_delay,na.rm = TRUE))

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'month'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.

flights_dep_delay_averages

# A tibble: 185 × 3
# Groups:   month [12]
   month carrier avg_dep_delay
   <int> <chr>           <dbl>
 1     1 9E              16.9 
 2     1 AA               6.93
 3     1 AS               7.35
 4     1 B6               9.49
 5     1 DL               3.85
 6     1 EV              24.2 
 7     1 F9              10   
 8     1 FL               1.97
 9     1 HA              54.4 
10     1 MQ               6.49
# ℹ 175 more rows



# Dataframe transformed from long to wide
flights_dep_delay_wide <- flights_dep_delay_averages |> 
  pivot_wider(
    names_from = carrier,
    values_from = avg_dep_delay
  )
flights_dep_delay_wide

# A tibble: 12 × 17
# Groups:   month [12]
   month  `9E`    AA     AS    B6    DL    EV    F9    FL    HA    MQ    OO

title: Practical 4
text:
Question 5

# Identify proportion of flights leaving late but arriving on time or earlier
prop_late_but_on_time <- flights |>
  summarise(
    proportion = mean(dep_delay > 0 & arr_delay <= 0, na.rm = TRUE)
  )
prop_late_but_on_time

# A tibble: 1 × 1
  proportion
       <dbl>
1      0.108


The proportion of flights out of the total flights that were delayed but still arrived on time is 0.1081096 or approximately 11%.

title: Practical 4
text:
Question 6

# load nycflights13 airlines data
data(airlines, package = "nycflights13") 
airlines <- as_tibble(airlines)
airlines

# A tibble: 16 × 2
   carrier name                       
   <chr>   <chr>                      
 1 9E      Endeavor Air Inc.          
 2 AA      American Airlines Inc.     
 3 AS      Alaska Airlines Inc.       
 4 B6      JetBlue Airways            
 5 DL      Delta Air Lines Inc.       
 6 EV      ExpressJet Airlines Inc.   
 7 F9      Frontier Airlines Inc.     
 8 FL      AirTran Airways Corporation
 9 HA      Hawaiian Airlines Inc.     
10 MQ      Envoy Air                  
11 OO      SkyWest Airlines Inc.      
12 UA      United Air Lines Inc.      
13 US      US Airways Inc.            
14 VX      Virgin America             
15 WN      Southwest Airlines Co.     
16 YV      Mesa Airlines Inc.         



6.1

# Identify unique combinations or origin, dest, and carrier
flights_routes <- flights |> 
  select(origin,dest,carrier) |>
  distinct() |> 
  group_by(origin,dest)
flights_routes

# A tibble: 439 × 3
# Groups:   origin, dest [224]
   origin dest  carrier
   <chr>  <chr> <chr>  
 1 EWR    IAH   UA     
 2 LGA    IAH   UA     
 3 JFK    MIA   AA     
 4 JFK    BQN   B6     
 5 LGA    ATL   DL     
 6 EWR    ORD   UA     
 7 EWR    FLL   B6     
 8 LGA    IAD   EV     
 9 JFK    MCO   B6     
10 LGA    ORD   AA     
# ℹ 429 more rows



# Isolate routes that are shared by multiple airlines
flight_routes_multiple_airlines <- flights_routes |> 
  count(origin,dest,name = "number_of_airlines") |> 
  filter(number_of_airlines>1)
flight_routes_multiple_airlines

# A tibble: 128 × 3
# Groups:   origin, dest [128]
   origin dest  number_of_airlines
   <chr>  <chr>              <int>
 1 EWR    ATL                    4
 2 EWR    AUS                    2
 3 EWR    BDL                    2
 4 EWR    BNA                    2
 5 EWR    BOS                    3
 6 EWR    BWI                    2
 7 EWR    CHS                    2
 8 EWR    CLE                    2
 9 EWR    CLT                    3
10 EWR    CVG                    2
# ℹ 118 more rows




6.2

# Identfiy all flights along the shared routes from Question 6.1
flights_multiple_airlines <- flights |>
  select(origin,dest,carrier,arr_delay) |>
  group_by(origin,dest,carrier) |> 
  semi_join(flight_routes_multiple_airlines,join_by(origin == origin, dest == dest))
flights_multiple_airlines

# A tibble: 276,735 × 4
# Groups:   origin, dest, carrier [343]
   origin dest  carrier arr_delay
   <chr>  <chr> <chr>       <dbl>
 1 JFK    MIA   AA             33
 2 LGA    ATL   DL            -25
 3 EWR    ORD   UA             12
 4 EWR    FLL   B6             19
 5 LGA    IAD   EV            -14
 6 JFK    MCO   B6             -8
 7 LGA    ORD   AA              8
 8 JFK    TPA   B6             -3
 9 JFK    LAX   UA              7
10 EWR    SFO   UA            -14
# ℹ 276,725 more rows



# Average flight delay for each airline along the shared routes
average_delay <- flights_multiple_airlines |> 
  summarise(mean_delay = mean(arr_delay,na.rm=TRUE))

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'origin', 'dest'. You can override using
the `.groups` argument.

average_delay

# A tibble: 343 × 4
# Groups:   origin, dest [128]
   origin dest  carrier mean_delay
   <chr>  <chr> <chr>        <dbl>
 1 EWR    ATL   9E           -6.25
 2 EWR    ATL   DL           10.00
 3 EWR    ATL   EV           19.5 
 4 EWR    ATL   UA           10.5 
 5 EWR    AUS   UA            4.28
 6 EWR    AUS   WN          -11.2 
 7 EWR    BDL   EV            6.78
 8 EWR    BDL   UA           22.6 
 9 EWR    BNA   EV           17.7 
10 EWR    BNA   WN           -2.13
# ℹ 333 more rows



# Added the names of each airline based on the "carrier" value from "airlines" data
average_delay_with_airline_name <- average_delay |> 
  left_join(airlines, by = join_by(carrier))
average_delay_with_airline_name

# A tibble: 343 × 5
# Groups:   origin, dest [128]
   origin dest  carrier mean_delay name                    
   <chr>  <chr> <chr>        <dbl> <chr>                   
 1 EWR    ATL   9E           -6.25 Endeavor Air Inc.       
 2 EWR    ATL   DL           10.00 Delta Air Lines Inc.    
 3 EWR    ATL   EV           19.5  ExpressJet Airlines Inc.
 4 EWR    ATL   UA           10.5  United Air Lines Inc.   
 5 EWR    AUS   UA            4.28 United Air Lines Inc.   
 6 EWR    AUS   WN          -11.2  Southwest Airlines Co.  
 7 EWR    BDL   EV            6.78 ExpressJet Airlines Inc.
 8 EWR    BDL   UA           22.6  United Air Lines Inc.   
 9 EWR    BNA   EV           17.7  ExpressJet Airlines Inc.
10 EWR    BNA   WN           -2.13 Southwest Airlines Co.  
# ℹ 333 more rows




6.3

# The airline's with the worst average delay for each route
max_delay <- average_delay_with_airline_name |> 
  group_by(origin,dest) |> 
  slice_max(mean_delay)
max_delay

# A tibble: 128 × 5
# Groups:   origin, dest [128]
   origin dest  carrier mean_delay name                    
   <chr>  <chr> <chr>        <dbl> <chr>                   
 1 EWR    ATL   EV           19.5  ExpressJet Airlines Inc.
 2 EWR    AUS   UA            4.28 United Air Lines Inc.   
 3 EWR    BDL   UA           22.6  United Air Lines Inc.   
 4 EWR    BNA   EV           17.7  ExpressJet Airlines Inc.
 5 EWR    BOS   B6            6.87 JetBlue Airways         
 6 EWR    BWI   EV           20.1  ExpressJet Airlines Inc.
 7 EWR    CHS   EV           16.2  ExpressJet Airlines Inc.
 8 EWR    CLE   UA            5.97 United Air Lines Inc.   
 9 EWR    CLT   EV           20.5  ExpressJet Airlines Inc.
10 EWR    CVG   EV           21.2  ExpressJet Airlines Inc.
# ℹ 118 more rows



# The airline's with the best average delay for each route
min_delay <- average_delay_with_airline_name |> 
  group_by(origin,dest) |> 
  slice_min(mean_delay)
min_delay

# A tibble: 128 × 5
# Groups:   origin, dest [128]
   origin dest  carrier mean_delay name                    
   <chr>  <chr> <chr>        <dbl> <chr>                   
 1 EWR    ATL   9E          -6.25  Endeavor Air Inc.       
 2 EWR    AUS   WN         -11.2   Southwest Airlines Co.  
 3 EWR    BDL   EV           6.78  ExpressJet Airlines Inc.
 4 EWR    BNA   WN          -2.13  Southwest Airlines Co.  
 5 EWR    BOS   EV          -4.01  ExpressJet Airlines Inc.
 6 EWR    BWI   WN           5.95  Southwest Airlines Co.  
 7 EWR    CHS   UA         -14     United Air Lines Inc.   
 8 EWR    CLE   EV          -3.71  ExpressJet Airlines Inc.
 9 EWR    CLT   US           0.920 US Airways Inc.         
10 EWR    CVG   9E           1.40  Endeavor Air Inc.       
# ℹ 118 more rows



# Combining the two tables of the best and worst airlines for each route
max_and_min_delays <- max_delay |> 
  left_join(min_delay,by = join_by(origin, dest)) |> 
  rename(max_carrier = carrier.x,
         max_mean_delay = mean_delay.x,
         max_name=name.x,
         min_carrier = carrier.y,
         min_mean_delay = mean_delay.y,
         min_name = name.y)
max_and_min_delays

# A tibble: 128 × 8
# Groups:   origin, dest [128]
   origin dest  max_carrier max_mean_delay max_name   min_carrier min_mean_delay
   <chr>  <chr> <chr>                <dbl> <chr>      <chr>                <dbl>
 1 EWR    ATL   EV                   19.5  ExpressJe… 9E                  -6.25 
 2 EWR    AUS   UA                    4.28 United Ai… WN                 -11.2  
 3 EWR    BDL   UA                   22.6  United Ai… EV                   6.78 
 4 EWR    BNA   EV                   17.7  ExpressJe… WN                  -2.13 
 5 EWR    BOS   B6                    6.87 JetBlue A… EV                  -4.01 
 6 EWR    BWI   EV                   20.1  ExpressJe… WN                   5.95 
 7 EWR    CHS   EV                   16.2  ExpressJe… UA                 -14    
 8 EWR    CLE   UA                    5.97 United Ai… EV                  -3.71 
 9 EWR    CLT   EV                   20.5  ExpressJe… US                   0.920
10 EWR    CVG   EV                   21.2  ExpressJe… 9E                   1.40 
# ℹ 118 more rows
# ℹ 1 more variable: min_name <chr>




6.4

# Added "difference" column to measure difference between the best and worst airlines per route
differences <- max_and_min_delays |> 
  mutate(difference = max_mean_delay - min_mean_delay) |> 
  ungroup()
differences

# A tibble: 128 × 9
   origin dest  max_carrier max_mean_delay max_name   min_carrier min_mean_delay
   <chr>  <chr> <chr>                <dbl> <chr>      <chr>                <dbl>
 1 EWR    ATL   EV                   19.5  ExpressJe… 9E                  -6.25 
 2 EWR    AUS   UA                    4.28 United Ai… WN                 -11.2  
 3 EWR    BDL   UA                   22.6  United Ai… EV                   6.78 
 4 EWR    BNA   EV                   17.7  ExpressJe… WN                  -2.13 
 5 EWR    BOS   B6                    6.87 JetBlue A… EV                  -4.01 
 6 EWR    BWI   EV                   20.1  ExpressJe… WN                   5.95 
 7 EWR    CHS   EV                   16.2  ExpressJe… UA                 -14    
 8 EWR    CLE   UA                    5.97 United Ai… EV                  -3.71 
 9 EWR    CLT   EV                   20.5  ExpressJe… US                   0.920
10 EWR    CVG   EV                   21.2  ExpressJe… 9E                   1.40 
# ℹ 118 more rows
# ℹ 2 more variables: min_name <chr>, difference <dbl>



# Identified route with biggest difference between best and worst airlines
greatest_diff <- differences |> 
  slice_max(difference)
greatest_diff

# A tibble: 1 × 9
  origin dest  max_carrier max_mean_delay max_name    min_carrier min_mean_delay
  <chr>  <chr> <chr>                <dbl> <chr>       <chr>                <dbl>
1 JFK    ATL   EV                     128 ExpressJet… 9E                    1.40
# ℹ 2 more variables: min_name <chr>, difference <dbl>


The route as per the above is JFK to ATL.


6.5

# Filtering for only the worst airline's flights along the route with the biggest difference
max_diff_flights <- flights |> 
  filter(origin == "JFK", dest == "ATL", carrier == "EV")
max_diff_flights

# A tibble: 1 × 19
   year month   day dep_time sched_dep_time dep_delay arr_time sched_arr_time
  <int> <int> <int>    <int>          <int>     <dbl>    <int>          <int>
1  2013    10     7      904            700       124     1133            925
# ℹ 11 more variables: arr_delay <dbl>, carrier <chr>, flight <int>,
#   tailnum <chr>, origin <chr>, dest <chr>, air_time <dbl>, distance <dbl>,
#   hour <dbl>, minute <dbl>, time_hour <dttm>



# Filtering for only the best airline's flights along the route with the biggest difference
min_diff_flights <- flights |> 
  filter(origin == "JFK", dest == "ATL", carrier == "9E")
min_diff_flights

# A tibble: 55 × 19
    year month   day dep_time sched_dep_time dep_delay arr_time sched_arr_time
   <int> <int> <int>    <int>          <int>     <dbl>    <int>          <int>
 1  2013     1     4      615            615         0      851            855
 2  2013     1     7      614            615        -1      812            855
 3  2013     1     8      612            615        -3      901            855
 4  2013     1     9      615            615         0       NA            855
 5  2013     1    10      613            615        -2      840            855
 6  2013     1    11      629            615        14      914            855
 7  2013     1    12      613            615        -2      839            855
 8  2013     1    13      612            615        -3      853            855
 9  2013     1    14      649            615        34      950            855
10  2013     1    15      612            615        -3      927            855
# ℹ 45 more rows
# ℹ 11 more variables: arr_delay <dbl>, carrier <chr>, flight <int>,
#   tailnum <chr>, origin <chr>, dest <chr>, air_time <dbl>, distance <dbl>,
#   hour <dbl>, minute <dbl>, time_hour <dttm>



# Histograms showing the disribution of all the flights along the route by the best and worst airlines
hist(max_diff_flights$arr_delay)







hist(min_diff_flights$arr_delay)








The difference arises due to the following. Firstly, on the JFK to ATL route, the airline 9E or Endeavor Air Inc, has many flights along this route with delays that appear to be normally distributed with a mean around 0, which can be seen in the “Histogram of min_diff _flights$arr_delay” plot above. On the other hand, the airline EV or ExpressJet Airlines only has one flight along the same route. In addition, that single ExpressJet Airlines flight had a very high arr_delay of 128, much higher than the maximum Endeavor Air delay of 55.
Having only a single flight results in a very high risk of an outlier skewing the results. In this case, 9E has a good average delay time, and due to EV’s one flight being so delayed, the difference between their averages is the biggest.

title: Practical 4
text:
Question 7

# Importing Question 7 code into "data" object
data <- structure(list(id = c("id_1", "id_2", "id_3", "id_4", "id_5", 
"id_6", "id_7", "id_8", "id_9", "id_10", "id_11", "id_12", "id_13", 
"id_14", "id_15", "id_16", "id_17", "id_18", "id_19", "id_20", 
"id_21", "id_22", "id_23", "id_24", "id_25", "id_26", "id_27", 
"id_28", "id_29", "id_30", "id_31", "id_32", "id_33", "id_34", 
"id_35", "id_36", "id_37", "id_38", "id_39", "id_40", "id_41", 
"id_42", "id_43", "id_44", "id_45", "id_46", "id_47", "id_48", 
"id_49", "id_50"), age = c(50L, 34L, 70L, 33L, 22L, 61L, 69L, 
73L, 62L, 56L, 71L, 33L, 73L, 44L, 45L, 46L, 24L, 70L, 46L, 76L, 
47L, 76L, 28L, 48L, 54L, 27L, 45L, 26L, 61L, 28L, 38L, 55L, 33L, 
36L, 62L, 58L, 72L, 31L, 34L, 51L, 61L, 64L, 26L, 28L, 60L, 29L, 
42L, 46L, 79L, 72L), gender = c("male", "male", "male", "female", 
"female", "male", "female", "male", "male", "female", "female", 
"male", "male", "female", "male", "male", "male", "male", "female",

[1] "_____________________"


Warning: Not all unique entries displayed for these non-numeric cols: id


From the above we can see that the columns that contain missing values include columns “height and”glucose”.
The column “gender” has one entry has a typo, as it says “femal” instead of “female”. Additionally, the “disease_status” column has one entry that has “Healthy” with a capital “H” whilst the other entries are “healthy” with a lowercase “h”.
Most columns that contain text are all lowercase, except for columns “region:” which all entries start with a capital letter, like “North” for example, and the “education” column, which has capitals in “PhD” entries.
The “id” column values all include the text “id_” which results in the column being formatted as “character” and not as “integer”. If you were to sort the data by the ID column the rows are not in the order you’d expect. As illustrated below, you can see the first row is “id_1” but then it jumps to “id_10” instead of “id_2”.

# Sorting data by the "id" column
class(data$id)

[1] "character"

data |> arrange(id)

title: Practical 1
text:
Question 1
# Load airquality data
airquality <- airquality
class(airquality)

[1] "data.frame"
# which returns the indices which meet a certain condition
a <- c()
for (col in 1:ncol(airquality)){
  a <- c(a, which(is.na(airquality[, col])))
}
a <- sort(unique(a))
a

 [1]   5   6  10  11  25  26  27  32  33  34  35  36  37  39  42  43  45  46  52
[20]  53  54  55  56  57  58  59  60  61  65  72  75  83  84  96  97  98 102 103
[39] 107 115 119 150
The above are all the rows that contain “na” values.
Alternatively, the same can be achieved by finding all rows that are NOT all non-na values:
# complete.cases provides a boolean for whether the whole observation is NA free
b <- which(!complete.cases(airquality))
print(b)

 [1]   5   6  10  11  25  26  27  32  33  34  35  36  37  39  42  43  45  46  52
[20]  53  54  55  56  57  58  59  60  61  65  72  75  83  84  96  97  98 102 103
[39] 107 115 119 150

title: Practical 1
text:
Question 2

# Remove all ozone values with na values
clean_ozone <- na.omit(airquality$Ozone)


# Find summary statistics of clean_ozone
min(clean_ozone); max(clean_ozone); mean(clean_ozone); sd(clean_ozone)

[1] 1


[1] 168


[1] 42.12931


[1] 32.98788



# Remove all temp values with na values
clean_temp <- na.omit(airquality$Temp)


# Find summary statistics of clean_temp
min(clean_temp); max(clean_temp); mean(clean_temp); sd(clean_temp)

[1] 56


[1] 97

title: Practical 1
text:
Question 4

# Linear Model to find actual estimates of B_hat
lm <- lm(dist ~ speed, data = cars)
summary(lm)


Call:
lm(formula = dist ~ speed, data = cars)

Residuals:
    Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
-29.069  -9.525  -2.272   9.215  43.201 

Coefficients:
            Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
(Intercept) -17.5791     6.7584  -2.601   0.0123 *  
speed         3.9324     0.4155   9.464 1.49e-12 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Residual standard error: 15.38 on 48 degrees of freedom
Multiple R-squared:  0.6511,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.6438 
F-statistic: 89.57 on 1 and 48 DF,  p-value: 1.49e-12



# B_hat coefficients
lm$coefficients

(Intercept)       speed 
 -17.579095    3.932409 


Here we have confirmed that B0 = -17.579095 and B1 = 3.932409.

title: Statistical Computing - Assignment 1
text:
This is the home page for my Quarto project for Assignment 1. The various practicals in this assignment can be found below:

Practical 1
Practical 3
Practical 4

title: Practical 3
text:
Question 5

# Generating the 1000 t-values
set.seed(100)
t.vals <- rt(1000,1)
sorted.t.vals <- sort(t.vals)
plot(sorted.t.vals)








QQ-plot, solution should look like:

qqPlot(sorted.t.vals, envelope = 0.95, ylim = c(-5, 5))








[1] 1000    1



# Generating a normally distributed data set to use as theoretical quantile values
set.seed(100)
normal_data <- rnorm(1000)
sorted_normal_data <- sort(normal_data)
plot(sorted_normal_data)









# creating matrix to simulate more normal data
normal_data_matrix <- matrix(rnorm(1000*1000), nrow = 1000, ncol = 1000)


# found upper and lower probability bands for the envelop
sorted_normal_data_matrix <- t(apply(normal_data_matrix,1,sort))
upper_ci <- matrix(nrow = 1000)
lower_ci <- matrix(nrow = 1000)
for (i in 1:1000){
  upper_ci[i]= quantile(sorted_normal_data_matrix[,i],0.975)
}
for (i in 1:1000){
  lower_ci[i]= quantile(sorted_normal_data_matrix[,i],0.025)
}


# Created QQ Plot with envelope
plot(sorted_normal_data, sorted.t.vals,
     main = "QQ Plot with Envelope",
     xlim = c(-4, 4),
     ylim = c(-5, 5)
     )
lines(sorted_normal_data, upper_ci, col = "red")
lines(sorted_normal_data, lower_ci, col = "red")
abline(0,1,col="blue")









# Comparison to qqPlot
qqPlot(sorted.t.vals, envelope = 0.95, ylim = c(-5, 5))








[1] 1000    1
